dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Things so bad, nobody can help -- not even Doctor Maxwell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctors and nurses can only do so much, Alma.  They can't cure everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctors that are people can't cure everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a puzzled look)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean -- "doctors that are people"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowly, almost sing-song)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are other doctors...Yes, other doctors...Better doctors...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the Houmfort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking off the idea)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's nonsense, Alma.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They even cure nonsense, Miss Betsy.  Mama Rose was mindless.  I was at the Houmfort when the Houngan brought her mind back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean Mama Rose was like Mrs. Holland?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  She was mindless but not like Miss Jessica.  But the Houngan cured her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you trying to tell me that the Houngan -- the voodoo priest -- could cure Mrs. Holland?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Miss Betsy.  I mean that.  The Houngan will speak to the rada drums and the drums will speak to Shango and Damballa.  The CAMERA MOVES IN to a CLOSE TWO SHOT of both women's faces,  Betsy looking thoughtfully at Alma and Alma retur the gaze with equal intensity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better doctors --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a small, plainly furnished room with a plain tabl few bentwood chairs and a medicine cabinet and a few washbasins and water pitchers on a shelf.  Mrs. Rand is kneeling down at the side of the little, black pickaninny rubbing ointment on a sore on his chest.  Betsy, in stree clothes, watcher her.  Mrs. Rand finishes her work on the little boy's chest and begins to put his little shirt bac him.  An obeah bag tied around his neck on a string gets her way as she tries to button the shirt.  She holds it u that the little boy can see it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ti-Peter, how do you ever expect to get to Heaven with one foot in the voodoo Houmfort and the other in the Baptist church?   The little black boy looks at her with rolling eyes but d not answer.  She gives him a playful pat on the behind, starting him on his way to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Betsy, cheerfully)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some of this native nonsense. The Houngan has his prescription and Dr. Maxwell and I have ours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've never said anything about voodoo before, Mrs. Rand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven't I?  I suppose I take it for granted. It's just part of everyday life here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't believe in it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A missionary's widow?  It isn't very likely, is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't mean believe, like believing in a religion.  I mean, do you believe it has power?  Do you think it could heal a sick person?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking hard at Betsy for a moment)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frankly, my dear, I didn't expect anything like this from a nice level-headed girl.  What are you driving at?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard the servants talking about someone called Mama Rose. They said she had been "mindless"...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her son drowned.  She brooded until her mind was affected. All the Houngan did was coax her out of it with a little practical psychology.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONG SHOT.  The camera is behind Betsy and Jessica as the toward the Houmfort through the sugar cane.  We see this voodoo temple as they go toward it.  It is a rickety structure of poles and laths, roofed over with a thin tha of sugar cane and straw.  It forms a sort of rude pergola In the center of this structure is a small, cubicle hut, of rough boards but neatly whitewashed.  From the rafters the main structure hang crude chandeliers of tin which gi light to the ceremonies. (Please see pages 28 to 31, Life Magazine, December 13, 1 All the details mentioned above are graphically illustrat Near the little hut in the center of the Houmfort, stands altar covered with a lace tablecloth and littered with a childish jumble of plates, candles, little colored stones bottles.  Before this altar stands the Houngan, the high priest of the voodoo ceremonies, a small, stoop-shouldere man in a worn, white coat and trousers with ragged cuffs. Several mild-looking negroes in white trousers and shirts in kitchen chairs on one side of the altar with rada drum between their knees.  Grouped around this altar in a loos semicircle are the worshippers, a group of mild-mannered, poorly-but-neatly-dressed negroes.  They seem to have mad effort to dress in their best and their best is very poor indeed.    As Betsy approaches, she can see familiar face As she comes up they turn and look at her.  They are not hostile nor greatly surprised; just mildly curious.  Lead Jessica by the hand, Betsy takes her place at one end of semicircle around the altar.  Her arrival has in no way interrupted the ceremonies.  The Houngan continues to cha before the altar, the rada drums beat and the crowd sings chorus of the Shango song at the proper intervals.  It is very decorous and decidedly religious in tone.  No sooner Betsy taken her place with the others than the Shango rit approaches its climax.  The Sabreur, a colored man dresse white shirt and trousers, with a neat dark tie knotted un his collar, comes in, bearing a sabre in his right hand, holding it in stately, almost processional manner.  He advances to the altar, strikes it three times and at this signal two colored women dressed in white beguine dresses with square cut necks, an essential part of this religiou costume, come forward.  One holds a white leghorn chicken the other carries a white rooster. They come together to altar and for a moment, the figures of the Houngan, the Sabreur and the two Mam-Lois hide the actual blood sacrif from us.  Only the fact that the drumming and the singing reach a climactic pitch reveal that some Important portio the ceremony has taken place.  Instantly the drumming and singing stops.  A young colored girl jumps up from her se among the worshippers and begins shivering and quaking, crying out wordlessly.  There is a cry from the people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put the god in her! Put the god in her! The Houngan prances forward, followed by the Sabreur. The Houngan holds a little saucer in his hand with some dark liquid at the bottom of it.  He dips four fingers into th liquid while the girl quivers and writhes before him in religious ecstasy.  He marks her forehead with four stran marks, one with each finger.  The Sabreur, crying out the name of Shango, four times, points his sabre to the four directions of the compass. There is an immediate transformation in the girl.  Her frenzy ceases.  She seem be filled with a jubilant calm and dances into the cleare space before the altar. Her words are no longer meaningle They have taken shape and form and, when she speaks, she speaks with great resonance as if her voice came from somewhere other than her own throat.  She is possessed by god, Shango. One by one, people from among the group of devotees dance into the circle, go up to her and beg for favors. One wom leads a little boy up to her.  We hear her words as she c out to the possessed girl:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make him rich, Shango!  Make him rich! The girl lays her fingers on the boy's eyes, and then tak his shoulders and turns him around three times, Evidently this is absolute guarantee of an enormous income tax to b paid at St. Sebastian.  The woman and her son retire happ pleased and grinning.  Finally, exhausted, the girl posse of the god, Shango, sinks to her knees and then falls fainting to the floor. Two colored men come in, carry her away.  A great cry rises from the voodoo worshippers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damballa!  Damballa!  Damballa! Damballa! The drums find a new rhythm.  The Houngan retires to one corner of the altar; the Sabreur to the other.  Two young girls, their beguine dresses slashed and torn, dance in f either side.  This is a wild and an impassioned dance, a dance to Damballa.  There is no singing, only an occasion call from the crowd, "Come to us, Damballa!" The dancers reach the climax of their dance and strike a plastic pose before the altar, each kneeling on one knee, their arms h to their breasts, their foreheads butted together.  Altho not a muscle moves, one can almost feel the tension of th two bodies.  One of the rada drummers comes up and crouch down holding a small drum almost under the chins of the t girls. The other drummers stop playing and he begins to beat a q staccato rhythm that grows faster and faster.  In this playing, as in the pose of the girls, there is tremendous tension.  By now all cries have ceased. Everyone is silen waiting.  Then suddenly, from behind the closed and curio painted door of the inner Houmfort, a voice speaks.  A vo that is light, pleasant and authoritative.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (muffled by the door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are my people?  Let them bring me the rice cakes -- let them dance and be happy -- There is a great ecstatic shout from the voodoo worshippe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damballa!  Damballa! The Sabreur dances forward, sword in his left hand and a little plate with rice cakes, in his right.  He kneels do and places the plate near the door jamb.  A line forms at door.  Betsy leading Jessica by the hand takes her place the rest.  She is third in the line of suppliants.  She c see the whole procedure.  The suppliant places his forehe against the forehead of the god painted on the door, and speaks.  The first suppliant is a weary-looking field han who shuffles to the door and speaks in such a low tone th his words cannot be heard.  The second suppliant is an ol woman, thin and work-worn.  She speaks sincerely and humb and Betsy, directly behind her, hears her words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damballa -- my son don't take care of me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him his own little son will grow big.  He, himself, will grow old.  The son learns from the father. One day your son may stand here to complain that his boy does not take care of him. The old woman turns away, comforted -- hopeful.  Betsy lo at her.  She can see tears in the old woman's eyes. With Jessica's hand in hers, Betsy takes her place at the door She puts her forehead against the crudely painted forehea the god.  She talks to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damballa! This woman is sick. The door swings open slowly. The feeble light of the oute Houmfort does not penetrate the darkness of the inner tem A hand reaches out from the darkness and takes Betsy's ha and draws her in. The Houngan follows Betsy into the temp The door shuts behind him. Jessica remains outside, stand before the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A match flares and a hand brings it forward to light an o lamp which flares brightly, revealing a little room of whitewashed boards, bare except for a table on which stan small iron tripod from which an iron pot is suspended. Although there is no fire under the pot, the steam rises this receptacle and water boils and bubbles in it. It is the Houngan who has lit the lamp and, on the other of the table is Mrs. Rand. Her face is serious and unsmil

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starting forward around the table)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Rand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait. Don't draw any conclusions. Let me explain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, Mrs. Rand --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew you'd come. And I knew I'd have to come up here and talk to you. I couldn't let you go back without any word. I came to tell you again -- Jessica cannot be cured.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But how did you get here? What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I asked you to let me explain. It's a long story.  And not an easy one --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jessica stands patiently where Betsy had left her. The Sabreur and two Mam-Lois stand near her looking at her an talking. We cannot hear what they say. The drumming and t song of joy for the coming of Damballa continue over the scene. Suddenly, as if he had arrived at some decision, t Sabreur, holding his sword stiffly in front of him, start toward Jessica with little mincing steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Rand, as if continuing with something she has been talking about for a long time --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and when my husband died I felt helpless. They disobeyed me -- things went from bad to worse. All my husband's dreams of good health, good sanitation, good morals for these sweet and gentle people seemed to die with him. (pauses)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, almost accidentally, I discovered the secret of how to deal with them. There was a girl with a baby -- again and again I begged her to boil the drinking water. She never would. Then I told her the god, Shango, would be pleased and kill the evil spirits in the water if she boiled it. She boiled the water from then on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you didn't have to come up here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps not.  But I did come here and I found it was so simple to let the gods speak through me. Once started, it seemed such an easy way to do good.  I should have known there was no easy way to do good, Betsy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betsy!  Get her away -- back to the Fort!  Do as I say -- they won't hurt you. ANOTHER ANGLE - SHOOTING TOWARD the inner Houmfort. Betsy runs out from the doorway, takes hold of Jessica's arm an starts running with her.  There is a movement in the crow if they were about to follow her.  From the doorway of th inner Houmfort, the Houngan calls out:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trouble.  Bad trouble.  Let her go. The crowd subsides.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betsy and Jessica pass quickly under the dead goat, on th way home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betsy comes out of the tower door, closing it behind her quietly and cautiously.  She starts across the garden tow her room.  From the shadows, Holland steps out barring he way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where have you been, Miss Connell? There is a pause.  Holland stands looking at her, taking her bedraggled appearance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wearily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to help you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help me? How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I took Mrs. Holland to the Houmfort.  I thought they might cure her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have deliberately endangered Mrs. Holland's life.  There's no telling what you may have started with this insanity.  Why did you do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a low tone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because you wanted to give my wife back to me?  Why should that mean anything to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not looking at him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know why.  You saw it the other night at the piano.  You turned away from me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (putting his hand on her shoulder, looking into her face very closely)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I saw the other night, I didn't dare believe, Betsy -- Betsy tries to turn away from him.  He grips her shoulder tightly. HOLLAND (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I was looking at a woman who loved me and had compassion for me.  Yet you made that trip to the Houmfort to bring Jessica back to me --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Holland pulls her close to him, looks down into her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think I love Jessica and want her back. It is like you to think that -- clean, decent thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (simply)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hated her. Betsy looks up at him, astounded by his words. HOLLAND (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her selfishness made her empty and dead.  She was a possession, a beautiful possession to own and hold -- but I never had a moment's peace or happiness with her. They stand there, close together, looking at each other.  Suddenly Holland puts her arms around her. HOLLAND (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betsy --  She lifts her face, with a smile of complete love and tru Holland studies her face longingly, but does not kiss her HOLLAND (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should never have brought you here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no happiness for me anywhere else -- Holland shakes his head slowly, hopelessly. BETSY (cont'd) (pleading)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul, I don't want you to be alone, unhappy -- Holland lets his arms drop from about her shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coldly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I may prefer it that way. They stand looking at each other.  The garden is still wi the dead, heavy stillness of their hopelessness.  Then, f the direction of the Houmfort, there is the sound of a si conch blowing, loudly and insistent, a thinner, higher ca than we have heard before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Rand, in a simple afternoon dress, is seated on the sofa.  Before her is a coffee table with a silver tea service.  She is engaged in pouring tea.  Betsy is beside helping her.  Rand, in working clothes, is in an armchair near the sofa with a highball in his hand.  Also seated, facing Mrs. Rand and Betsy, is Dr. Maxwell and Commission Jeffries.  The latter is a dignified man of early middle- He is dressed in a light business suit.  At the window, a the rear of the room, stands Holland, talking with a Prie As the scene opens, Mrs. Rand fills a teacup and holds it toward Holland.  He comes toward her to pick up the cup, Priest walking with him.  As they walk, Holland speaks:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I assure you, Father Walters, Miss Connell had no idea of the consequences when she went there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul, we're not trying to blame Miss Connell.  It isn't a question of blame.  It's a question of what we are to do with Jessica.  The commissioner is very concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It has become a serious problem.  There's so much gossip, rumor and agitation about the whole thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.  We've felt it at the mill.  The men could hardly keep their minds on their work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Jeffries, why come to us about it?  Why don't you go up to the Houmfort and put a stop to the drumming and dancing -- that's what causes all the trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  You're quite wrong.  Right here's the seat of the trouble.  Mrs. Holland has become an object of speculation and religious interest to these people.  It's revived all their old superstitions -- Zombies -- and that sort of nonsense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't worry too much, Commissioner.  It'll pass.  We've had this sort of thing before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is something else.  They're curious.  Curiosity and religious fervor make a strange and explosive mixture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm quite sure nothing will happen, Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I were as sure as you, Mrs. Rand, we wouldn't be here.  I'll tell you quite bluntly: for the peace of the island and possibly for her own safety, we've come to ask you to send Mrs. Holland away to St. Thomas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To the asylum?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe there's a kinder name for it, Wesley. At St. Thomas, it's called the Institute for Mental Therapy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter what you call it.  I can tell you right now Jessica isn't going! Dr. Maxwell looks first at him, then at Holland, then bac Rand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fortunately, Wesley, this isn't a matter for your decision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean to say Paul can send her away -- that he can hand her over to strangers -- who'll shut her up  - maybe mistreat her?  He hasn't that right!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to calm him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wesley!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am afraid, Wesley, he has that right.  And I will have to urge him to use it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tell you he hasn't and he wouldn't dare use it if he had.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because he drove Jessica insane -- deliberately -- coldly! They all look at Holland.  There is a long and awkward pa Holland makes no move to deny by word or gesture his brother's accusation.  Finally, however, he breaks the pa by bringing the teacup to his lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That could be a serious accusation, Rand, if it weren't a foolish one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Foolish?  Tell them how foolish it is, Paul -- tell them!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very calmly but with a little uncertainty)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My guilt in this matter, if any, Wesley, is not the subject of this discussion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it is, Paul!  Because that's why you won't dare send Jessica away! Holland empties his teacup. Carrying the teacup and sauce very carefully, he walks across to the table in front of Betsy, and sets it down.  Betsy looks at him.  It is on h look, questioning and puzzled, that we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Although it is broad daylight, the Inner Houmfort is lit a rush light which burns weakly.  The ceremonial pot of boiling water has been removed from the table and, in its place, squatting cross-legged like a tailor, sits the Sabreur. With one hand he holds upright a small, cheaply- bisque doll, with flaxen hair.  It is dressed in a little white slip.  From under the table rim, two dark feminine hands come up to put a white robe on the doll.  The momen this garment has been draped on the little doll, a rada d begins to beat softly in a corner of the room. THE CAMERA DRAWS BACK to reveal that one of the girls who danced in the voodoo ceremony is kneeling before the tabl It is her hands which have dressed the doll.  There are a five people in the room, including the three drummers.  T Sabreur makes magical passes over the doll.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betsy and Holland are standing in the gateway.  The CAMER POINTED TOWARD the garden.  On the porch in the b.g. we c see Mrs. Rand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I still can't believe it Paul -- that you wouldn't say a word in your own defense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no defense.  So far as I know -- it is true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't believe that.  You don't know what viciousness it would take to drive a person mad.  You're not vicious or cruel, Paul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know I'm not?  I was cruel to Jessica.  When I got to know her -- when I found out how empty and ungenerous she was, there was something about her -- something smooth and false -- that made we want to hurt her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can understand that.  Everyone feels that way about someone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  It's not just how I felt toward Jessica.  I've been cruel to even you. Besty, smiling, shakes her head. HOLLAND (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first night I saw you -- you were looking at the sea.  You were enchanted -- and I had to break that enchantment.  Do you understand, Betsy -- I had to break it! Betsy is shaken by this, but she tries to put it aside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanted to warn me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disregarding her words)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The night you came to me in this room -- to comfort me, to help me -- I turned you away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't, Paul -- don't doubt yourself -- don't make me doubt you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember words I said to Jessica  - words mixed like to poison -- to hurt her, to madden her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (desperately)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's past -- that's over and done with...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to be safe, Betsy.  I want to know you're away from this place -- home again, where nothing can harm you -- nothing and no one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. They stand looking at each other in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Rand is seated in an easy chair, obviously enjoying interlude of leisure.  Clement comes from the house, brin her a bulky newspaper, still in its mail wrapper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like to see the paper, Mrs. Rand? (proudly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is our newest one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you , Clement! She takes it and starts slitting the wrapper eagerly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betsy and Holland start across the garden to the porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Rand seems them and waves a section of the paper in welcome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're just in time.  Will you join me in the Sunday paper? Betsy and Holland sink into porch chairs, looking gratefu for the shade.  Betsy takes off her hat and tosses it ont the coffee table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Considering that the paper is three months old and this isn't Sunday -- no thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess I'll wait until I'm home, Mrs. Rand. Mrs. Rand looks at a page of rotogravure section.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (casually)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a long wait...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid not.  Betsy's leaving us, Mother. Mrs. Rand puts down the paper and looks at them, startled HOLLAND (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's decided to go on the next boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, Betsy -- we can't lose you.  You mean too much to us here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's sweet of you, Mrs. Rand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betsy feels there is nothing she can do for Jessica...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rand and Dr. Maxwell come through the gate and walk up th garden path.  As they do so, Mrs. Rand comes down the por steps.  Betsy and Holland follow her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Maxwell -- it's nice to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grimly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Maxwell has very unpleasant news for us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nervously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An accident at the mill?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- it's about Mrs. Holland.  A result of our discussion the other day, I'm afraid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In view of all the circumstances, the commissioner has decided on a legal investigation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Investigation of what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of the nature of Mrs. Holland's illness.  And, of course, the events which led up to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In other words, I'm on trial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did everything I could to forestall this, Paul.  I don't think there's any question of your innocence in the matter.  But there's been too much talk.  The thing's out of hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe it's better this way, Mother.  I'm glad you're going home, Betsy -- you'll be out of the mess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she isn't.  She's been subpoenaed. Holland turns to the Doctor, his face stricken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Connell's testimony will be very important.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would have stayed anyway, Dr. Maxwell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're all in it.  There won't be a shred of pride or decency left for any of use. (violently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say something, Paul!  You've always been good with words.  Put some together, now, and tell us that you're not responsible -- that every damnable bit of it doesn't rest squarely on your shoulders!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're wrong, Wesley.  The guilt is mine -- all of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bitterly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you going to lie for him, Mother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betsy, tell them about the Houmfort.  Tell them what you saw there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (protestingly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Rand...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must, Betsy. They'll have to believe you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reluctantly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Rand was at the Houmfort that night.  But there's nothing wrong with that.  She's gone there for years -- trying to take care of those people,  to help them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I do.   (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've often talked a little voodoo to get medicine down a patient's throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's more than that, Doctor.  I've entered into their ceremonies - pretended to be possessed by their gods... They stare at her, dumbfounded. MRS. RAND (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what I did to Jessica was worse than that.  It was when she going away with Wesley.  There was that horrible scene. She turns to Rand. MRS. RAND (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You thought she loved you, didn't you?  She didn't.  She didn't love anyone except herself  -- her reflection in the mirror, the look she could bring into a man's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That isn't true.  You never understood her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disregarding his protest)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That night, I went to the Houmfort.  I kept seeing Jessica's face -- smiling -- smiling because two men hated each other -- because she was beautiful enough to take my family in her hands and break it apart.  The drums seemed to be beating in my head.  The chanting -- the lights --  everything blurred together.  And then I heard a voice, speaking in a sudden silence.  My voice.  I was possessed.  I said that the woman at Fort Holland was evil and that the Houngan must maker her a Zombie. Dr. Maxwell has been studying Mrs. Rand with a curious, intent expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what happened then, Mrs. Rand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unsteadily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hated myself.  I kept saying to myself over and over again that these people had no power; they had no strange drugs; that there is no such thing as a Zombie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah -- that's where reason took hold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I said it, and I made myself believe it. But when I got here, Jessica was already raging with fever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two things had happened, Mrs. Rand.  One was that your daughter-in-law had been taken ill with a fever.  The other thing -- completely disconnected -- was that you had wished her ill, because she had hurt your sons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (protesting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I had no thought of harming her.  It wasn't I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were possessed.  That is true -- possessed by your subconscious mind.  You were in the Houmfort, surrounded by their symbols.  To them, nothing worse can happen to a person than to be made into a Zombie.  Your subconscious mind used their own words for evil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Maxwell is right, Mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently and kindly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emotion tricks all of us, Mrs. Rand.  And you are a woman with a very strong conscience.  That conscience has been tormenting you.  The rest is coincidence.  There is no such thing as a Zombie.  The dead do not come back to life.  Death is final. From the hills comes the sound of a single conch, loud an thin. The CAMERA PANS from the group around Mrs. Rand to the to door.  Jessica walks out of it and comes slowly past the fountain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA IS FOCUSED ON a little five-and-ten-cent store doll about three inches high.  It is dressed in a crude imitation of Jessica's loose, belted, white gown.  A thre is tied around it and this thread leads off, taut. The CAMERA PANS ALONG the thread to show us that the othe end of the thread, some twenty feet long, is held by a ne crouched near the altar.  Halfway between this man and th doll, the Sabreur, his sword stuck in the mound before hi straddles the thread, his hands clasped around the thread not touching it.  Carre-Four stands watching. The conch is blowing its strange, magnetic call and the negroes are chanting as they watch the Sabreur and the do The Sabreur makes motions as if he were pulling on the th but still does no touch it.  He makes these motions over over again.  The doll moves slowly.  Then suddenly stops. The Sabreur's most frantic efforts fail to move it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANOTHER ANGLE -- Jessica comes slowly past the fountain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jessica! She does not seem to hear but continues walking toward th gate.  We hear the sound of running feet.  Holland and Be run up to Jessica.  Holland takes her arm, but she contin to walk forward.  He tries to hold her.  It is apparent h cannot do so without the use of considerable force.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jessica!  Jessica! She pays no attention but continues to move forward towar the gate.  Betsy, realizing that is something outside of previous experiences with the woman, has the presence of to run forward and slam shut the great wrought-iron gate. Jessica walks up against the gate and stands there, unabl move any further.  They stand and look at her perplexed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doll has stopped moving.  The Sabreur is exerting all force.  We can see the sweat soaking his white shirt.  Th others are chanting, louder now, swaying in rhythm with h pulling movements.  The conch is being blown with a more insistent and compelling note.  Still, the doll-figure refuses to move.  The Sabreur stops.  The conches are suddenly silenced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In this sudden silence, Holland and Jessica look at each other across the motionless figure of Jessica.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Houmfort -- they're trying to get her back there. Betsy and Holland look at each other.  Then Betsy takes Jessica's arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come with me, Jessica. Obedient again, Jessica allows Betsy to turn her around a lead her back to the open tower door.  As Betsy and Jessi go into the bedroom, the door closes behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT of an enormous black hand.  The fingers of thi hand are spread out limply.  On this hand stands the litt five-and-ten-cent store doll which represents Jessica.  F beneath this hand, another smaller black hand comes in an closes the great fingers around the doll. The CAMERA PULLS BACK to show the exterior of the Houmfor The light is fading.  The posts of the Houmfort and the figures of several voodoo worshippers are outlined in silhouette against the darkening sky.  A single rada drum being beaten in light, quick rhythm.  Someone sets fire t heaped-up bonfire of dry leaves.  The flames blazing up illuminate the scene more clearly, so that we can see a s group of voodoo adepts squatting on their heels in a ring around the bonfire.  Near the bonfire stand Carre-Four an the Sabreur, with the drummer crouched behind them.  The Sabreur takes the doll from Carre-Four's hand and holds i foot or so away from him.  The great black hand reaches f it.  Again the Sabreur takes the doll away and dances off with mincing steps to a distance of a few yards.  Carre-F lumbers after him, his hand extended.  Again, the Sabreur lets him take the doll. CLOSE SHOT of Carre-Four's hand with the doll upon it.  F underneath, the smaller hand of the Sabreur comes in and closes the great black fingers over the little white doll

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is in darkness.  In the faint light from the bar windows, we see Betsy sleeping on the chaise lounge.  A shadow moves across her face.  Through the window, we see great, cadaverous figure of Carre-Four.  His hand closes around the bars, his face presses against them.  Then he go of the bars and slips out of sight.  His figure reappe at the next window.  Again, he tries the bars and peers i the room.  Again, he vanishes in the darkness.  We hear a faint sound from the tower.  Betsy wakens.  Her eyes go quickly to the bed, where the outline of Jessica's figure reassures her.  There is another muffled, dragging sound the tower.  Betsy sits up, listens intently.  She gets up goes toward the door leading into the tower.  At the foot Jessica's bed, she stops to grab up Jessica's white negli throwing it around her she continues to the door and open slowly and cautiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betsy steps into the lower tower room.  The thick blackne of the place is faintly lit by the open door into Jessica windowed bedroom.  She stands at the foot of the circling stone stairs, straining to see into the darkness above.  Overhead, there is a sudden commotion of wings and shrill - something has disturbed the bats.  Very slowly and hesitantly, Betsy moves up a few steps. The CAMERA PANS UP from Betsy, around the circling walls the stairs, to where the sharp blade of light from the sl window of the tower strikes across the wall.  A big black hand slides down the shaft of light.  The CAMERA PANS BAC Betsy.  She can see nothing, but she hears the dry, whispering sound of the hand moving along the wall.  She backs down the few steps and across to the tower door lea to the garden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betsy slips out of the tower door.  She stands irresolute by the fountain, watching and listening.  She can see not in the black patch of the open tower door.  She walks slo into the garden.  There is a faint sound behind her.  Fearfully, Betsy looks back across her shoulder.  She see shadow slip into the deeper shadows of the fountain, merg with them.  Quickly she moves behind a tall shrub, looks again toward the tower.  She sees nothing. A CLOSE SHOT of the fountain shows the surface of the wat in the cistern broken by a spreading ring of ripples.  Ta with fear, Betsy leaves the shadow of the tall shrub and slips over to a bush nearer the living room porch.  As if answer to this move, a whispering rustle comes from the screen of bamboo against the tower-wing of the house.  Sh stares toward the bamboo.  She sees nothing. A CLOSE SHOT of the bamboo shows the leaves trembling slightly.  Betsy looks across the empty, defenseless spac between herself and the porch steps.  Steeling herself, s moves into it, walking with the slowness of nightmare fea looking from side to side with the slightest possible mov her head.  At the foot of the steps, she turns to look ba at the bamboo.  A distorted shadow slithers out from unde the stalks.  Her panic released, Betsy runs up the steps, down the shadowy porch to the door of Holland's bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a very low, choked cry)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul...Paul... She flings herself against the door, turns the handle, an runs into the room, closes the door behind her.  Into the space before the porch steps moves the great gaunt figure Carre-Four.  This is our first full sight of him in the scene.  He is bare to the waist, wearing only a pair of d ragged trousers.  He starts up the steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betsy comes out of the door to Holland's bedroom, followe Holland who has put on a robe.  In a CLOSE SHOT, we see t shock that springs into their two faces as they see Carre Four facing them across the length of the porch, moving toward them, a single slow step at a time.  As Carre-Four sees Betsy's white-clad figure, his hands come up slowly his sides.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You!  What are you doing here? Carre-Four continues his slow, implacable move forward. lifted hands start reaching outward. HOLLAND (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out of here. Carre-Four comes on relentlessly, his great arms outstret toward Betsy, the enormous hands curving to seize her.  F comes into Holland's face.  With a quick gesture, he pres Betsy back and steps in front of her. HOLLAND (cont'd) (a little uncertainly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out of here -- Carre-Four is almost upon them.  His shoulders press forw as he reaches out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quiet, with great authority)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carre-Four! The single word freezes Carre-Four into immobility.  Astounded, Betsy and Holland turn to see Mrs. Rand at the end of the porch -- her face and hair pale above a dark, like robe. MRS. RAND (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carre-Four.  Go back. Slowly, the giant figure obeys.  Carre-Four turns to face her.  His hands relax, his arms fall to his sides again.  In his blind fashion, Carre-Four moves back across the po turns and goes down the steps to the garden.  Holland, wh has been watching this transfixed, starts after him. MRS. RAND (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul! Holland pauses at the head of the stairs and turns to her MRS. RAND (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let him go.  Don't touch him, don't try to stop him! Betsy has come down the porch behind Holland and she and Rand stand together.  All three of them look into the gar Carre-Four slips through the gates and is immediately los sight in the darkness of the road beyond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Betsy steps into her room, she sees Rand standing by o of the windows.  In his face and his posture are complete dejection, utter misery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betsy, can I talk to you a minute?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with quiet sympathy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, Wes. She waits, inquiringly.  Rand takes a few steps into the and turns to stare through the door, across the garden to Jessica's room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does she suffer?  Does she know what she is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. (trying to ease the truth)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I once asked Dr. Maxwell the same question.  He said he thought she was like a sleepwalker who would never waken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hated sleep.  She used to say it was a thief -- stealing away her life, an hour at a time...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to speak lightly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not to a nurse.  Sleep is a cure. Betsy crosses to the dressing table and takes a small cot stoppered bottle from a drawer.  She pulls out the cotton shakes two little pills into her hand. BETSY (cont'd) (going to Rand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In fact, I'm prescribing sleep for you right now. She puts them into his hand. BETSY (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be a good patient.  Take these and go to bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's dead.  The dead ought to be buried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she's not dead, Wes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (violently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what she is!  That's death -- no mind, no senses -- no love, no hate, no feeling -- nothing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Wes, do as I ask.  You must rest, you must sleep. Rand turns his hand and lets the tablets fall to the floo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dully)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She should have rest. (looking up at Betsy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shouldn't have to walk and walk, in that black emptiness. (with realization)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could set her free.  You could give her rest.  You could give her rest. Betsy, alarmed and troubled, puts her hand on his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't think of it, Wes.  I couldn't do that. Rand turns and takes hold of her arm pleadingly, urgently

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could do it.  You have drugs -- it would be so quick -- a single injection.  If you won't do it for her sake, do it for Paul. Betsy shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Wes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jessica was never any good for Paul.  You will be, you are.  And Mother -- seeing Jessica day after day -- never able to escape, never able to forget.  Please, Betsy -- it's only merciful. He looks into her eyes and sees the finality of her refus there.  His hand drops from her arm and he turns away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with great pity)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her heart beats, Wes.  She breathes.  That's life -- I once took an oath to guard life. Rand straightens up and takes a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.  I shouldn't have asked it. He starts slowly to the open door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Houngan and the Sabreur are working over the doll aga It begins to move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHOOTING TOWARD the gates from behind Rand where he still sits at the table.  Jessica, dressed in a white nightgown comes slowly out of the tower and moves toward the gates. Rand watches her.  The gate stops her progress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doll has stopped despite the frenzied efforts of the Sabreur and the wild chanting of the voodoo adepts.  Noth can make it move again.  There is a whispered consultatio between the Sabreur and the Houngan.  The Houngan lifts h hand and the drums begin to beat a light rapid rhythm. The Sabreur dances toward the doll, making a menacing mov with his saber.  When he reaches the little image, he put the point of his saber in the ground and draws from his bodkin, a long needle.  With one swift movement, he stabs this through the doll's back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As seen from Rand's ANGLE.  He rises slowly, drains the liquor in his glass, walks forward to where Jessica stand the gate.  He looks at her for a long moment and then, as a resolve had formed in his mind, goes to the statue of S Sebastian, takes hold of one of the iron arrows.  He tugs it, but it refuses to come free.  He puts his foot up on wooden breast of the statue and gives a hard pull.  The l iron arrow comes out in his hand.  With this in his hand, walks to where Jessica stands.  He pulls back the latch b and throws the gates wide open.  Jessica moves out into t darkness.  Rand follows her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHOOTING TOWARD the gates.  Jessica, followed by Rand, wa into the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kettle of water, without a fire, is still boiling.  T CAMERA MOVES AROUND the room to show that it is empty.  T MOVES UP ON a small shelf before which a candle is burnin On this shelf, a few inches above the candle flame, stand the cheap little doll dressed like Jessica, with the need in its back.  Suddenly, the doll falls forward on its fac

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rand carrying Jessica's dead body in his arm, comes down the sand. The surf.  Rand reverently places the body in the lapping water of the surf.  The backward drag of an outgoing wave draws it silently away from him.  He watches it go. A returning wave, tall and forward curving, upthrusts the body of Jessica so that we see it in the semi-transparenc the wave. MED. CLOSE SHOT of Rand.  The body comes floating to his feet. Rand carries the body a little further into the surf so t the waves when they come in flow past his knees.  Again, outsurge takes the body away. A returning wave brings Jessica's body back again.  (Ther a famous painting by Boecklin, called "And the Sea Gave U its Dead" which should somewhat influence the composition this scene.) MED. CLOSE SHOT -- Rand.  He walks forward to secure the returning body.  This time, he picks it up in his arms an starts wading forward. Rand is walking forward with the body in his arms.  The s is up to his hips.  The outgoing surge tugs at him.  He struggles to regain his footing, misses and is drawn out sea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stars seem to have fallen to the surface of the sea. see lights here and there, only a few feet from the water flaring and sparkling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. LONG SHOT.  This is a closer shot of the scene and identifies the lights.  There are torches held in the han of black fisherman, up to their knees in water, spearing flounders by torch light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSEUP -- flounder fisherman.  He is moving slowly throu the shallow water his spear raised.  Suddenly, he makes a darting strike with his spear.  With a cry of triumph, he holds aloft a struggling flounder.  He disengages it from spear and puts it into the sack slung from his belt. MED. CLOSE SHOT -- another fisherman.  He, too, is moving stealthily forward, spear poised, torch held low.  Something on the surface of the water near-by attracts hi attention and he lifts up his torch, the periphery of the light widening as he holds it aloft.  The widening light reveals the dead body of Jessica afloat on the surface of water, pallid and dreamlike, her wet, white garments clin like cerements.  The fisherman looks for a moment at the and then calls off to one of the other fishermen. LONG SHOT -- flounder fishermen, their lights all converg on a central light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. CLOSE SHOT.  A group of flounder fishermen come out the land.  They are carrying the bodies of Jessica and Ra They start in the direction of Fort Holland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fishermen come in bearing their tragic burdens.  Rand body is carried on the shoulders of four fishermen.  Behi walks Carre-Four and in his gigantic arms is the body of Jessica; her wet hair and garments dripping from the grea arms of the still-living Zombie.  The upheld torches and spears of the fishermen give a weird, processional feelin the group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holland, Betsy and Mrs. Rand stand watching the fishermen bringing in the bodies of the dead.  Across the garden fr the fountain stands the little group of house servants al watching.  The procession passes the fountain of St. Sebastian and the CAMERA GOES IN to show the glistening s face of the saint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA, as in the first portion of the script, PANS D the sign, pausing for a moment at the firm name of the Parrish & Burden Sugar Company.  Then it CONTINUES ITS DOWNWARD MOVEMENT to disclose a portion of the street its In the falling snow Betsy is standing with her back to th camera, looking up at the sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (narration)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a sad time at Fort Holland.  Mother Rand was completely broken by the tragedy. But she's a woman of   courage. She's begun to build up her  life again at St. Sebastian -- It's a good life and a full one.  As for Paul and me -- it wasn't a simple problem for either of us. A CLOSER SHOT of Betsy as she stands waiting.  She is dre in a fur-collared coat and has a little round fur cap on head.  She looks very attractive and very happy.  The doo the office opens and Paul Holland comes out, muffling up overcoat.  Betsy takes a half step to meet him.  He takes arm with a well-used and familiar gesture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry to keep you waiting, darling!  I thought I'd never get away.  Invoices and stock lists piling up all day long.  The balmy tropics were never like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (giving his arm a little squeeze as they start walking toward the camera)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't have minded waiting.  I never mind waiting for you -- only we're dining with the Wilkins.  I don't want it said all over Ottowa that the Hollands are always late. They pass the camera which HOLDS for a moment on the sign the falling snow, then we
